Windows 11 is sleek, fast, and full of features‚Äîbut like most modern operating systems, it collects a lot of data about how you use your device. By default, Microsoft enables several settings that send diagnostic information, personalize ads, and track your activity across devices.

If you value your privacy, it‚Äôs worth taking a few minutes to adjust these settings. Here are the **most important Windows 11 privacy settings you should change right now**.

## 1. Turn Off Advertising ID Tracking

Windows 11 assigns an **advertising ID** that helps apps show you personalized ads. While it doesn‚Äôt expose your personal identity, it still tracks how you use apps and the web.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí General**
- Toggle off: **‚ÄúLet apps show me personalized ads by using my advertising ID.‚Äù**

## 2. Limit Diagnostic Data Collection

Microsoft collects diagnostic data to improve Windows, but you can limit how much is sent.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí Diagnostics & Feedback**
- Select **‚ÄúRequired diagnostic data‚Äù** instead of ‚ÄúOptional diagnostic data.‚Äù
- Scroll down and turn off **‚ÄúTailored experiences.‚Äù**

## 3. Disable Location Tracking (Unless You Really Need It)

Location services are useful for maps or weather apps, but not everyone wants constant tracking.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí Location**
- Toggle off **Location services** or disable location access for specific apps.

## 4. Manage App Permissions

Many apps request access to your **camera, microphone, contacts, and more**‚Äîeven if they don‚Äôt need it.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí App permissions**
- Review each category (Camera, Microphone, Contacts, etc.) and turn off access for apps that shouldn‚Äôt have it.

## 5. Stop Windows From Tracking Your Typing & Inking

Windows can collect typing and handwriting data to improve text suggestions. If that feels intrusive:

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí Inking & Typing personalization**
- Toggle off **‚ÄúPersonal inking and typing dictionary.‚Äù**

## 6. Disable Activity History Syncing

Windows can save your activity history (apps, websites, documents) and sync it across devices.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Privacy & Security ‚Üí Activity History**
- Uncheck **‚ÄúStore my activity history on this device‚Äù** and **‚ÄúSend my activity history to Microsoft.‚Äù**

## 7. Control Background Apps

Background apps can consume resources and quietly send data.

- Go to: **Settings ‚Üí Apps ‚Üí Installed apps**
- For each app, click the three dots ‚Üí **Advanced options**
- Under ‚ÄúBackground apps permissions,‚Äù choose **Never** for apps you don‚Äôt need running in the background.

üí° **Pro tip:** Revisit these settings after major Windows updates‚Äîsometimes Microsoft resets preferences back to defaults.
